workout_file.description: Foundation training: Relatively low intensity ride with goal of spending a large proportion of the ride into Endurance Zone 2.
workout_file.name: Week 1.1 - Foundation

textevent.message: Hello, and welcome to the 6 Week Beginner FTP Builder! I'm glad you're here.
Each of these workouts will start with a progressive warmup to ensure you're ready for the work ahead.
The cadence goal here is just something to aim for, but please do what's comfortable for you to start.
That's 3min into the warmup now. Keep taking things nice and easy and start bringing your cadence up to around 85 RPM.
Let's also do a quick check to make sure you have fluids, a fan, and a towel. These items are crucial for any Zwift session.
Also, be sure you are taking frequent sips of fluid throughout these workouts and keeping yourself hydrated.
That's halfway through our warmup today. Let's go over what we have in store for today...
Today, the plan is to spend 20min working in zone 2, aka 'Endurance' zone and is the 'blue' zone on Zwift.
We're going to be breaking that 20min up by doing 5, 4min efforts, separated by 2min of recovery.
We'll also be changing up the cadence with each interval, and on-bike positions.
Over the course of the next 6 weeks, we're going to increase the total time spent in this zone steadily.
And our final workouts will be more than double the time we're spending in zone 2 today :-)
This steady increase is called progressive overload and is key to improving your fitness.
Let's enjoy the next few minutes of the warmup and keep easing into the day, and we'll catch up with 30sec to go.
All right, in 30sec, our first interval begins. Nothing too fancy, 4min steady at 72% FTP.
I want you to keep your cadence slow on this first one, and aim for 70 RPM.
Ready? Start bringing the cadence down...
Here we go, bring the cadence down to about 70 RPM and use this first minute to adjust.
If you don't have a cadence sensor, aim for just over 1 complete pedal stroke per second.
Good work so far. Now, aim for consistency in the next 3min: silky smooth pedaling and steady power.
That's halfway! Do a quick upper body check. Are your shoulders relaxed? Loosen the tension in your hands.
The final minute of this first rep! Keep up with the rock-solid form.
There's the arch; keep going until you're through it.
Excellent, now bring the cadence up to something a bit more comfortable.
Let's recover for a couple of minutes.
That should not have felt too challenging, but even still, try to take some deep breaths here.
Remember to take a couple of sips of fluid during the rest breaks, too, especially if you are bad at drinking during a workout.
Okay, 30sec until our next rep. This time, we're going to the other end of the cadence spectrum.
I want you to aim for 95-100 RPM next and pick the pace up with your leg speed..
Ready? Start bringing the leg speed up here.
Here we go, same power target, BUT much faster cadence.
If you don't have a cadence sensor, aim for about 1.5 pedal strokes per second now.
Okay, you should be adjusted to this faster cadence. Now, let's aim for consistency again.
Let's do another quick form check. At higher cadences, make sure you're not bouncing or lurching in the saddle too.
Final 30sec here. Keep the cadence from dropping for this last bit.
Great work! Let's bring it down again to recover and rest. That's 2 down, and 3 to go :-)
Coming up in 30sec is our 3rd interval. This time we're going to be going from sitting to standing.
We're going to be alternating 20sec of standing with 1min of sitting, 4 times.
We're starting seated and at a comfortable cadence, ready?
All right, let's ease into this interval again here.
Coming up in 10sec, we're going to stand up for 20sec at 65 RPM, ready?
Stand up here, slow your cadence down, and aim for smoothness in your pedal stroke.
Great job, now sit back down again and resume a comfortable cadence.
In 10sec, get ready to stand back up again...
Stand up, drop the cadence again.
Great work! 2 down, 1 to go. Let's sit down again and spin comfortably.
Get ready for another 20sec of standing...
Stand up once again. Try to make the transition from sitting to standing smooth.
Final 10sec to go, keep it up!
Awesome work! Let's take it easy for a couple of minutes again. We have 2 intervals to go.
All right, our next, and 4th, interval is going to have us working at a slow cadence again.
So, just like before, we're aiming for 4 minutes at 70 RPM.
Ready? Start to slow your cadence down again...
Let's make this 4th interval look just as good as the 1st! Use this first minute to adjust.
And remember, if you don't have a cadence sensor, aim for just over 1 complete pedal stroke per second.
Great work! That's halfway through this one. It's okay if your legs are starting to feel some fatigue.
That's all part of the training and stimulus we're trying to create today, and with the progressive nature of this plan.
Just 30sec to go, and you've done it!
Nice work! Back up to a comfortable cadence again now. Just 1 interval left today
This last one is going to have us alternating fast cadence, with a low cadence, for 1min each.
We're going to start at 70 RPM, then go up to 100 RPM, 2 times.
Ready? Start to slow your cadence down again...
In 10sec, we're going to transition up to 100 RPM. Try to make the increase in cadence smooth.
All right, bring your cadence back up again now without just smashing the pedals to make it happen.
And smoothly slow the legs down again.
Back up again - FAST FEET!
Last 10sec! Get to that arch!
Way to go!! Let's bring the cadence down to something comfortable and start our cool down.
We'll steadily ramp it down to 40% FTP over the next 10min.
You crushed it today, excellent work!
You shouldn't need too much recovery after a workout like this but aim for 24 hours between sessions, if possible.
We'll see you next time!
